article:
2022 Brazilian General Election

The 2022 Brazilian general election was held on October 2, 2022, to elect the President, Vice President, and members of the National Congress and state legislatures. The election was marked by a polarized campaign and concerns about democratic stability.

# Background

The 2022 election took place in the context of a deepening economic crisis, high levels of unemployment, and rising inflation. The COVID-19 pandemic had also had a significant impact on the country, with Brazil being one of the worst-affected countries in the world. The election was seen as a crucial moment for Brazil's democracy, with many analysts warning of the risks of authoritarianism and the erosion of democratic institutions.

# Electoral System

## Voters

All Brazilian citizens aged 18 and over were eligible to vote, provided they were registered on the electoral roll. Voting was compulsory for citizens between the ages of 18 and 70, and optional for those over 70 and for 16- and 17-year-olds.

## Candidates and Political Parties

A total of 11 candidates ran for the presidency, representing a range of political parties and coalitions. The main candidates were Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, the former President of Brazil and leader of the Workers' Party (PT), and Jair Bolsonaro, the incumbent President and leader of the Liberal Party (PL).

## Procedure

The presidential election was held in two rounds. In the first round, voters chose their preferred candidate, and the top two candidates with the most votes advanced to a runoff. In the second round, voters chose between the two remaining candidates, with the winner being the candidate with the most votes.

# Presidential Candidates

## Candidates in Runoff

* Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva (PT)
* Jair Bolsonaro (PL)

## Candidates Not Advanced to Runoff

* Simone Tebet (MDB)
* Ciro Gomes (PDT)
* Soraya Thronicke (UNIÃO)
* Luiz Felipe d'Avila (NOVO)
* José Maria Eymael (DC)
* Léo Péricles (UP)
* Sofia Manzano (PCB)

## Withdrawn or Declined to Be Candidates

* Geraldo Alckmin (PSB)
* João Doria (PSDB)

## Coalitions

Several coalitions were formed during the campaign, including the "Let's Go Together for Brazil" coalition, which supported Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, and the "Always Forward" coalition, which supported Jair Bolsonaro.

# Congress

Elections were also held for the National Congress, which consists of the Chamber of Deputies and the Federal Senate. A total of 513 deputies and 81 senators were elected.

# Campaign

## Debates

Several debates were held during the campaign, including a presidential debate on September 29, 2022.

# Incidents

## Political Violence

There were several incidents of political violence during the campaign, including attacks on candidates and their supporters.

### Notable Cases

#### June–August

* On June 12, 2022, a supporter of Jair Bolsonaro was arrested for attacking a group of Lula supporters in São Paulo.
* On July 22, 2022, a candidate for the Chamber of Deputies was shot and killed in Rio de Janeiro.

#### September–October

* On September 12, 2022, a group of Bolsonaro supporters attacked a group of Lula supporters in Brasília.
* On October 1, 2022, a candidate for the Federal Senate was stabbed in São Paulo.

## Disinformation

There were widespread concerns about disinformation during the campaign, with many fake news stories and conspiracy theories circulating on social media.

## Electoral Fraud Allegations

There were several allegations of electoral fraud during the campaign, including claims of vote-buying and manipulation of the electoral roll.

### Reactions to Potential Coup

#### International Reactions

There were concerns about the potential for a coup in Brazil, with many international leaders and organizations expressing concern about the stability of the country's democracy.

## Voter Suppression Attempts

There were several attempts to suppress voter turnout during the campaign, including efforts to intimidate voters and restrict access to polling stations.

### In the First Round

#### Intimidation of Voters

There were several reports of voter intimidation during the first round of the election, including incidents of armed men attempting to prevent voters from casting their ballots.

### In the Second Round

There were several attempts to suppress voter turnout during the second round of the election, including efforts to restrict access to polling stations and intimidate voters.

## Environmental Issues

There were several environmental issues during the campaign, including concerns about deforestation and climate change.

## Views and Endorsements

Several notable figures endorsed candidates during the campaign, including former President Fernando Henrique Cardoso, who endorsed Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva.

# Opinion Polls

# Aftermath

## Analysis

### Presidential Election Results

The presidential election was marked by a high level of polarization, with many voters expressing strong support for one of the two main candidates.

### Congressional Election Results

The congressional elections saw a significant shift in the balance of power, with several parties gaining or losing seats.

## Reactions

### In Brazil

There were widespread celebrations in Brazil following the announcement of the election results, with many supporters of Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva expressing joy and relief.

### Abroad

The international community reacted to the election results with a mixture of congratulations and concerns, with many leaders and organizations expressing hope for a smooth transition of power.

## Transition of Power

article:
Jude Bellingham

Jude Victor William Bellingham is an English professional footballer who plays as a midfielder for La Liga club Real Madrid and the England national team. He has been widely regarded as one of the most promising young players in the world, known for his exceptional vision, passing range, and goal-scoring ability.

#Early life and education

Bellingham was born on June 29, 2003, in Stourbridge, West Midlands, England. He grew up in a family of football enthusiasts and began playing the sport at a young age. Bellingham attended Priory School in Birmingham and later enrolled in the Birmingham City Academy, where he began his formal football education.

#Club career

##Birmingham City

Bellingham joined the Birmingham City Academy at the age of seven and quickly rose through the ranks. He made his professional debut for the club on August 6, 2019, at the age of 16, becoming the youngest player to ever start a match for Birmingham City. Bellingham went on to make 44 appearances for the club, scoring four goals and providing two assists.

##Borussia Dortmund

###2020–2021: Transfer and record-breaking achievements

In July 2020, Bellingham signed a five-year contract with Borussia Dortmund, reportedly worth £22 million. He became the most expensive 17-year-old in football history at the time. Bellingham made his debut for the club on September 14, 2020, and quickly established himself as a key player in the team. He scored his first goal for the club on November 7, 2020, and went on to score 11 goals in his debut season, becoming the youngest player to reach double figures in the Bundesliga.

###2021–2023: Bundesliga Player of the Season and league runner-up

In the 2021–22 season, Bellingham continued to impress, scoring 19 goals and providing 14 assists in all competitions. He was named the Bundesliga Player of the Season, becoming the youngest player to ever win the award. Bellingham also helped Borussia Dortmund finish as runners-up in the Bundesliga, narrowly missing out on the title.

##Real Madrid

###2023–24: Debut season and goalscoring records

In June 2023, Bellingham signed a six-year contract with Real Madrid, reportedly worth £115 million. He became the most expensive English player in history at the time. Bellingham made his debut for the club on August 12, 2023, and quickly established himself as a key player in the team. He scored his first goal for the club on August 26, 2023, and went on to score 15 goals in his debut season, breaking the record for the most goals scored by an English player in a single season in La Liga.

###2024–25: Second season and European Super Cup

In the 2024–25 season, Bellingham continued to impress, scoring 12 goals and providing 10 assists in all competitions. He helped Real Madrid win the European Super Cup, scoring a goal in the final. Bellingham also helped the club reach the quarterfinals of the Champions League, where they were eliminated by Manchester City.

#International career

##Youth career

Bellingham has represented England at various youth levels, including the under-15, under-16, under-17, and under-21 teams. He made his debut for the under-21 team on November 15, 2019, at the age of 16, becoming the youngest player to ever start a match for the team.

##Senior career

Bellingham made his senior debut for England on November 12, 2020, at the age of 17, becoming the third-youngest player to ever start a match for the team. He scored his first goal for the team on June 13, 2021, and has since become a regular member of the squad.

##UEFA Euro 2024

Bellingham was named in the England squad for the UEFA Euro 2024, where he played a key role in the team's run to the semifinals. He scored two goals and provided two assists in the tournament, helping England reach the semifinals, where they were eliminated by Spain.

#Style of play

Bellingham is a highly skilled and versatile midfielder, known for his exceptional vision, passing range, and goal-scoring ability. He is comfortable playing in a variety of positions, including central midfield, attacking midfield, and even as a striker. Bellingham is also known for his exceptional work rate, pressing ability, and tackling skills, making him a complete midfielder.

#Outside football

Bellingham is known for his humble and down-to-earth personality, often speaking about the importance of staying grounded and focused on his football career. He is also known for his charity work, often visiting hospitals and schools to meet with young fans and inspire them to pursue their dreams.

article:
Collapse of Silicon Valley Bank

The collapse of Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) was a significant financial event that occurred in 2023, resulting in the failure of one of the largest banks in the United States. SVB was a major financial institution that served the tech industry and had a significant presence in Silicon Valley. The bank's collapse had far-reaching consequences for its customers, shareholders, and the broader financial system.

# Background

Silicon Valley Bank was founded in 1983 and had grown to become one of the largest banks in the United States, with over $200 billion in assets. The bank was known for its expertise in serving the tech industry and had a significant presence in Silicon Valley, where many of its clients were based. SVB had a strong reputation for providing innovative financial solutions to its clients, which included many of the world's leading tech companies.

In the years leading up to its collapse, SVB had experienced rapid growth, driven in part by the booming tech industry. The bank had expanded its operations to include a range of financial services, including venture capital and private equity investing. However, this rapid growth had also led to concerns about the bank's risk management practices and its exposure to the tech industry.

# Collapse

The collapse of SVB began in early 2023, when the bank announced that it was facing significant losses due to a decline in the value of its investment portfolio. The bank's portfolio was heavily weighted towards long-term bonds, which had declined in value due to rising interest rates. As a result, SVB was facing significant losses, which it struggled to absorb.

## Losses

The losses faced by SVB were significant, with estimates suggesting that the bank had lost over $10 billion in the months leading up to its collapse. These losses were driven by a combination of factors, including the decline in the value of its investment portfolio and a decline in the value of its loan portfolio. The bank's loan portfolio was heavily weighted towards the tech industry, which had been experiencing a downturn in recent months.

## Instability

As the losses mounted, SVB began to experience instability. The bank's customers began to withdraw their deposits, which put pressure on the bank's liquidity. The bank's stock price also declined significantly, which made it difficult for the bank to raise capital. The instability at SVB was further exacerbated by concerns about the bank's risk management practices and its exposure to the tech industry.

## Receivership

In an effort to stabilize the bank and prevent further losses, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) took control of SVB in March 2023. The FDIC placed the bank into receivership, which allowed it to take control of the bank's assets and operations. The FDIC's takeover of SVB was seen as a necessary step to prevent further instability in the financial system.

## Acquisition

Following the FDIC's takeover of SVB, the bank was acquired by another financial institution. The acquisition was seen as a positive step, as it allowed the bank's customers to continue to access their accounts and provided stability to the financial system.

# Effects

The collapse of SVB had significant effects on its customers, shareholders, and the broader financial system.

## Customers

The collapse of SVB had a significant impact on its customers, many of whom were tech companies. The bank's customers were forced to find new banking arrangements, which was a challenging and time-consuming process. Many of the bank's customers also experienced difficulties in accessing their accounts, which caused significant disruption to their businesses.

## Shareholders

The collapse of SVB also had a significant impact on its shareholders. The bank's stock price declined significantly in the months leading up to its collapse, which resulted in significant losses for its shareholders. Many of the bank's shareholders were also forced to sell their shares at a loss, which further exacerbated their losses.

## Financial system

The collapse of SVB had significant implications for the broader financial system. The bank's collapse was seen as a potential threat to the stability of the financial system, as it had significant connections to other financial institutions. The collapse of SVB also raised concerns about the risk management practices of other financial institutions and the potential for further instability in the financial system.

## Legal actions

In the aftermath of the collapse of SVB, several legal actions were taken against the bank's executives and directors. These actions alleged that the bank's executives and directors had engaged in reckless and negligent behavior, which had contributed to the bank's collapse.

# Reactions

The collapse of SVB sparked a range of reactions from officials, regulators, and commentators.

## Official responses

The official response to the collapse of SVB was swift and decisive. The FDIC took control of the bank and placed it into receivership, which allowed it to stabilize the bank and prevent further losses. The Federal Reserve also provided emergency funding to the bank, which helped to stabilize the financial system.

## Debate over government intervention

The collapse of SVB sparked a debate over the role of government intervention in the financial system. Some commentators argued that the government should have intervened earlier to prevent the bank's collapse, while others argued that the government's intervention was necessary to prevent further instability in the financial system.

## Debate about causes

The collapse of SVB also sparked a debate about the causes of the bank's failure. Some commentators argued that the bank's failure was due to its reckless and negligent behavior, while others argued that the bank's failure was due to external factors, such as the decline in the tech industry.

The eighth season of the American television series The Masked Singer premiered on September 21, 2022, and concluded on November 30, 2022. The season featured a new format, with a rotating panel of guest judges and a variety of themed episodes.

# Panelists and host

The season featured a rotating panel of guest judges, including Ken Jeong, Jenny McCarthy Wahlberg, Nicole Scherzinger, and Robin Thicke. The host of the show was Nick Cannon.

The season was produced by Fox Alternative Entertainment and was filmed at the Television City Studios in Los Angeles, California. The show was executive produced by Craig Plestis, Izzie Pick Ibarra, and Nick Cannon.

# Contestants

The season featured 22 contestants, each wearing a unique costume and mask to conceal their identity. The contestants were divided into three groups: Group A, Group B, and the Wildcard contestants. The contestants competed against each other in each episode, with one contestant being eliminated at the end of each episode.

article:
A. L. Zissu

A. L. Zissu was a Romanian Jewish Hasidic scholar, journalist, and activist who played a significant role in the country's Jewish community during the mid-20th century. Born into a prominent Hasidic family, Zissu's life was marked by his dedication to Jewish scholarship, his advocacy for Religious Zionism, and his resistance against Nazi persecution and communist oppression.

#Biography

##Hasidic scholar and journalistic debut
A. L. Zissu was born in 1888 in the town of Târgu Neamț, in the historical region of Moldavia, Romania. His family was part of the local Hasidic community, and from a young age, Zissu demonstrated a keen interest in Jewish scholarship. He received a traditional Hasidic education, studying under prominent rabbis and Torah scholars. Zissu's intellectual curiosity and writing talent soon led him to pursue a career in journalism. In 1910, he began writing for the Romanian Jewish newspaper "Egalitatea," where he published articles on Jewish culture, history, and politics.

##Religious Zionism
Zissu's involvement in journalism coincided with the rise of the Zionist movement in Romania. He became an ardent supporter of Religious Zionism, advocating for the return of Jews to the Land of Israel. Zissu saw Zionism as a means to revitalize Jewish identity and ensure the survival of the Jewish people. Through his writings, he encouraged Romanian Jews to engage with Zionist ideology and participate in the movement's activities.

##Nazi persecution
The rise of Nazi Germany and its influence in Eastern Europe had a profound impact on Zissu's life and work. As the Nazi Party's anti-Semitic policies intensified, Zissu became increasingly vocal in his opposition. He wrote scathing critiques of Nazi ideology and its impact on Jewish communities, using his journalistic platform to raise awareness about the growing threat. Zissu's activism did not go unnoticed, and he soon became a target of Nazi persecution.

##Resistance movement
In 1940, Zissu joined the Romanian Jewish resistance movement, which aimed to counter Nazi influence and protect Jewish communities. He worked closely with other resistance leaders, coordinating efforts to smuggle Jews out of Romania and into Palestine. Zissu's involvement in the resistance movement put him at great personal risk, but he remained committed to the cause, using his journalistic skills to disseminate information and rally support.

##Jewish leadership
In 1944, Zissu was appointed to the Romanian Jewish Community Council, a leadership body that represented Jewish interests in the country. As a member of the council, Zissu worked to promote Jewish welfare, education, and culture. He also played a key role in negotiating with the Romanian government, advocating for Jewish rights and protection.

##Against communism
Following World War II, Romania fell under communist rule, and Zissu's activism shifted to oppose the new regime. He saw communism as a threat to Jewish identity and the Zionist movement, and he wrote extensively about the dangers of communist ideology. Zissu's anti-communist stance put him at odds with the Romanian authorities, who viewed him as a subversive element.

##Securitate set-up and imprisonment
In 1959, Zissu was arrested by the Securitate, Romania's secret police, on charges of treason and anti-communist activities. The arrest was a setup, and Zissu was subjected to intense interrogation and torture. Despite the mistreatment, he refused to renounce his Zionist beliefs or cooperate with the authorities.

##Trial, reprieve, and death
Zissu's trial was a sham, and he was sentenced to life imprisonment. However, due to international pressure and the efforts of Jewish organizations, Zissu's sentence was commuted to house arrest in 1964. He died in 1973, at the age of 85, his health broken by years of imprisonment and mistreatment.

#Legacy

A. L. Zissu's legacy is that of a courageous Jewish leader who fought tirelessly against oppression and advocated for Jewish rights and identity. His commitment to Religious Zionism and his resistance against Nazi and communist regimes serve as an inspiration to future generations. Through his writings and activism, Zissu left an indelible mark on the history of Romanian Jewry, and his memory continues to be celebrated and honored today.

article:
Eurovision Song Contest 2023

The Eurovision Song Contest 2023 was the 67th edition of the Eurovision Song Contest, an annual international song competition held among member countries of the European Broadcasting Union (EBU). The contest took place in Liverpool, United Kingdom, following the EBU's decision to transfer the hosting rights from Ukraine, the winner of the 2022 contest, due to the ongoing conflict in the country.

# Location

The 2023 contest was hosted by the United Kingdom, with the city of Liverpool selected as the host city.

## Host country selection

On June 17, 2022, the EBU announced that the 2023 contest would not be held in Ukraine, the winner of the 2022 contest, due to the ongoing conflict in the country. The EBU subsequently opened a bidding process for the hosting rights, which was won by the United Kingdom.

## Host city bidding phase

The host city bidding process was launched on July 25, 2022, and seven cities submitted bids: Birmingham, Glasgow, Leeds, Liverpool, Manchester, Newcastle, and Sheffield. On October 7, 2022, the EBU announced that Liverpool had been selected as the host city.

# Participating countries

A total of 37 countries participated in the 2023 contest, including returning countries such as Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, and North Macedonia.

## Returning artists

Several artists returned to the contest in 2023, including Loreen, who represented Sweden in 2012 and 2023, and Mahmood, who represented Italy in 2019 and 2023.

## Other countries

Several countries, including Russia and Belarus, were not eligible to participate in the 2023 contest due to their exclusion from the EBU.

# Production

The 2023 contest was produced by the BBC, in collaboration with the EBU.

## Visual design

The visual design of the contest was created by the BBC's in-house design team, led by creative director, Kate McKenzie.

## Stage design

The stage design was created by Turkish designer, Es Devlin, and featured a large, curved screen and a central performance area.

## Postcards

The postcards, which introduced each country's performance, were filmed in various locations across the United Kingdom and featured a mix of cultural and scenic footage.

## Vocal rules

The EBU introduced new vocal rules for the 2023 contest, which required all vocals to be performed live during the performances.

## Presenters

The 2023 contest was presented by a team of four presenters: Graham Norton, Alesha Dixon, Hannah Waddingham, and Julia Sanina.

# Format

The contest format remained largely the same as in previous years, with two semi-finals and a final.

## Voting system and contest structure

The voting system and contest structure remained the same as in previous years, with a 50/50 split between jury and public voting.

## Semi-final allocation draw

The semi-final allocation draw took place on January 31, 2023, and determined the running order for the two semi-finals.

# Contest overview

## Semi-final 1

The first semi-final took place on May 9, 2023, and featured 15 countries. The top 10 countries qualified for the final.

## Semi-final 2

The second semi-final took place on May 11, 2023, and featured 16 countries. The top 10 countries qualified for the final.

## Final

The final took place on May 13, 2023, and featured the 20 qualified countries, plus the "Big Five" countries (France, Germany, Italy, Spain, and the United Kingdom).

### Spokespersons

Each country's spokesperson announced the jury points during the final.

# Broadcasts

The 2023 contest was broadcast in over 180 countries, including the United States, Australia, and Canada.

# Reception

## Commercial impact

The 2023 contest generated significant commercial revenue, with a total of €100 million in sponsorship and advertising revenue.

## Reaction to the results

The reaction to the results was mixed, with some countries expressing disappointment and others celebrating their success.

## Broadcasting awards

The 2023 contest won several broadcasting awards, including the prestigious Rose d'Or award.

# Other awards

## Marcel Bezençon Awards

The Marcel Bezençon Awards were presented to the winners of the contest, including the winner of the Press Award, the Artistic Award, and the Composer Award.

## OGAE

The OGAE (Organisation Générale des Amateurs de l'Eurovision) awards were presented to the top five countries in the contest, as voted by OGAE members.

## You're a Vision Award

The You're a Vision Award was presented to the country with the most visually stunning performance, as voted by the public.

## Eurovision Awards

The Eurovision Awards were presented to the winners of the contest, including the winner of the Best Song, Best Performance, and Best Singer awards.

# Official album

The official album of the 2023 contest was released on May 12, 2023, and featured all 40 songs from the contest.

## Charts

The official album charted in several countries, including the United Kingdom, Germany, and Australia.

## Certifications

The official album was certified gold in several countries, including the United Kingdom and Germany.
